newsitem.title: USA: Protest comic books target Disney on Haiti.
newsitem.headline: Protest comic books target Disney on Haiti.

text.p: One item handed out at Walt Disney Co's summer movie "Hercules" differs from the usual for-profit souvenirs -- a coloring book in which the film's cartoon stars call for better conditions for workers in Haiti.

"Will Hercules do the right thing -- or will he slowly turn into a greedy, complacent has-been just like Disney's leaders?" the book asks, saying workers at Disney-licensed plants in the Caribbean country make just $0.28 per hour.
The Disney movie is based on the myth of Hercules, an ultra-strong ancient Greek.

The Miami Herald Friday quoted a member of a group called the Modern Action Club, which is distributing the coloring books, as saying they were first distributed in June at Disney's Hercules kickoff parade in New York.

Disney officials were not immediately available for comment. The company has denied allegations that workers are exploited at plants in Haiti that manufacture Disney-licensed products. It says it has a code of conduct for its licensees and their manufacturers that is strictly monitored and enforced.
